name: pleonastic
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
using more words than are needed to express a meaning, either unintentionally or for emphasis: The prose is often pleonastic in nature. Some pleonastic phrases, such as "tuna fish" or "advance reservation", become part of normal idiom. Related word
pleonasmCompare
tautological
More examplesFewer examples"Get it for free" is pleonastic - it is only necessary to say "Get it free". Out of context, the prepositional phrases may look pleonastic. The pleonastic use of the third person personal pronoun seems to have been common in all periods of English.Pleonastic redundancy does not make a phrase ungrammatical.
